quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 6 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 6.9: Hydrogen Bonding and Its Special Properties
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: A hydrogen bond is a specific, strong type of dipole-dipole attraction that occurs when hydrogen is bonded to:
options: Fluorine, Oxygen, or Nitrogen ($F, O, N$)
Any nonmetal in the periodic table
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonding only occurs with the three most electronegative elements ($F, O, N$) because they create a very large partial positive charge on the hydrogen atom.

questions.question: Why are hydrogen bonds significantly stronger than regular dipole-dipole forces?
options: The large electronegativity difference and small size of the hydrogen atom allow for close, strong attractions.
Hydrogen bonds involve the sharing of electron pairs between nuclei.
Hydrogen bonds are actually a type of metallic bond.
The hydrogen atom develops a full $+1$ ionic charge.
questions.explanation: Because hydrogen is small and its single electron is pulled away by $F, O,$ or $N$, the bare nucleus can get very close to the lone pairs of a neighboring molecule.

questions.question: Which of the following molecules exhibits hydrogen bonding?
questions.explanation: Water contains $O-H$ bonds, which are one of the three requirements for hydrogen bonding.

questions.question: What unique property of water is a direct result of extensive hydrogen bonding?
options: Ice is less dense than liquid water, causing it to float.
Water has an extremely low boiling point for its mass.
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonds organize water molecules into an open, hexagonal crystal lattice when frozen, increasing the volume and decreasing the density.

questions.question: Which substance would you expect to have the highest boiling point?
questions.explanation: Despite being the smallest, $HF$ has the strongest intermolecular forces (hydrogen bonding), requiring much more energy to vaporize.

questions.question: Hydrogen bonding is responsible for holding together the two strands of which biological molecule?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonds between nitrogenous bases (adenine-thymine and cytosine-guanine) maintain the double-helix structure.

questions.question: In a hydrogen bond between two water molecules, the attraction is between:
options: The $\delta+$ Hydrogen of one molecule and a lone pair on the Oxygen of another.
The two Oxygen nuclei of adjacent molecules.
Two Hydrogen atoms from different molecules.
A Hydrogen nucleus and an Oxygen nucleus within the same bond.
questions.explanation: The 'bond' is an intermolecular attraction between the positive pole of one molecule and the negative lone pair of another.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a requirement for a hydrogen bond to form?
options: The molecule must contain a metal atom.
Hydrogen must be covalently bonded to $F, O,$ or $N$.
A neighboring molecule must have a lone pair on an $F, O,$ or $N$ atom.
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonding is an intermolecular force between nonmetal molecular compounds, not metals.

questions.question: Ethanol ($C_{2}H_{5}OH$) has a much higher boiling point than dimethyl ether ($CH_{3}OCH_{3}$) even though they have the same formula ($C_{2}H_{6}O$). Why?
options: Ethanol can form hydrogen bonds, while dimethyl ether cannot.
questions.explanation: Ethanol has an $-OH$ group capable of hydrogen bonding, whereas in the ether, the oxygens are not bonded to hydrogens.

questions.question: Water's high surface tension, which allows some insects to 'walk' on it, is caused by:
options: The strong cohesive forces of hydrogen bonding.
The high density of water molecules.
The magnetic field of the Earth.
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonds pull the surface molecules inward, creating a 'skin' or film at the surface of the liquid.
